Updated April 8, 2025, 12:19 p.m. ET

Florida made history with its 2025 men's NCAA Tournament championship game victory on Monday night.

The Gators defeated Houston 65-63, erasing a 12-point deficit at the Alamodome in San Antonio, Texas, to claim their first national championship since 2007. In doing so, Florida picked up its third national championship in basketball, which tied Villanova for the eighth most championships in college basketball history.

With three national titles in basketball (2006, 2007 and 2025), Florida is the only school to have won three NCAA Division I titles in both men’s basketball and football (1996, 2006 and 2008). The Gators are also the only school to win a national title in basketball and football in the same academic year (2006-07).

According to the NCAA, Michigan State has three national championships in football (1952, 1965 and 1966) and two in college basketball (1979 and 2000), bringing them the closest to Florida for the new NCAA benchmark.

With Monday's victory, the Gators snapped a 13-year-drought for the SEC with a national championship in basketball. Kentucky won the national title in 2013 as the last SEC school before Florida.

Florida football national championships

Florida football has won three national championships in football. Steve Spurrier led the program to its first championship in 1996, while Urban Meyer led the Gators to two championships in three years in 2006 and 2008.

1996: Florida 52 , Florida State 20

, Florida State 20 2006: Florida 41, Ohio State 14

Ohio State 14 2008: Florida 21, Oklahoma 14

Florida men's basketball national championships

In his third season with the program, Florida coach Todd Golden led the Gators to its third national championship in school history in 2025. Billy Donovan led the Gators to back-to-back national championships in 2006 and 2007, the first two in program history. Donovan also led Florida to a national championship appearance in 2000, a loss to Tom Izzo and Michigan State.

search_result.title: James: Ranking the Top 10 quarterbacks in Notre Dame history
search_result.text:
Tyler James | South Bend Tribune

ND Insider

April 7, 2020, 5:00 p.m. ET

This list scared me.

Lists have become a staple of sports writing, because they’re enjoyable to write, they bring back memories and they’re fun to debate. That’s why you’ve seen so many lists in the Tribune and other publications in recent weeks.

But when I decided to pick the top 10 quarterbacks in Notre Dame football history, the task became intimidating.

There are far too many great Irish quarterbacks to fit into a list of 10. That much was clear. As I dove into media guides for bios, records and recaps, I started to realize that my list would exclude Heisman Trophy winners, national champions and first-round NFL Draft picks.

All three of those honors would be important categories for evaluating each résumé, but they represented only a fraction of the subjective formula.

When working through which quarterbacks to leave off my list, I decided to put stock in repeated success. That put John Huarte, despite his phenomenal 1964 Heisman season, on the chopping block. I also didn’t want to give a player credit for the impact he made playing other positions. That’s part of why the versatile Paul Hornung, also an elite kick return and safety, became a cruel cut from the list.

So what did I put stock in? Not all categories were given the same weight, but I tried to account for various honors (Heisman voting, All-American status, NFL Draft pick), winning (career wins, winning percentage, national titles) and statistics (completion percentage, passing yards and touchdowns, rushing yards and touchdowns).

Consider this a warning for Joe Montana’s place on the list: A quarterback’s professional accolades did not hold any value. I only went as far as a player’s NFL Draft selection as another way to measure how that quarterback compared to his peers.

In order to balance the statistics of quarterbacks from vastly different eras of college football, NCAA statistical rankings from specific seasons were also considered. That combined with national honors should have leveled the playing field a bit.

But that’s enough explaining. I can almost guarantee you’re going to disagree with my list. I’m ready to hear your complaints. I want to see your top 10 lists too.

I’ve put this off for long enough. Let’s get to the list.

1. Johnny Lujack (1942-43, 46-47)

The length of Lujack’s résumé was too much for any other quarterback to overcome. He won three national championships, became a two-time unanimous All-American and took home the 1947 Heisman Trophy.

As a sophomore in 1943, Lujack was given the reins of coach Frank Leahy’s T formation when the Marine Corps called quarterback Angelo Bertelli into service for World War II with four games remaining in the season. Lujack stepped up to lead the Irish to victory over three Top 10 teams. A loss in the season finale to Great Lakes didn’t prevent Notre Dame from being crowned national champions.

Lujack left Notre Dame to serve in the Navy, but he returned in time for the 1946 season. In his final two seasons, Lujack never lost a game on his way to winning two more national titles. His 20-1-1 record as a starting quarterback remains the program’s best in winning percentage (.932).

Lujack capped his Notre Dame career with a Heisman season in which he completed 56% of his passes (61-of-109) for 777 yards and nine touchdowns and rushed 12 times for 139 yards and one touchdown. The Chicago Bears selected Lujack with the fourth overall pick of the 1948 NFL Draft.

2. Brady Quinn (2003-06)

Notre Dame’s 2019 media guide listed Quinn with at least a tie for first place in 30 different individual program records. He holds the season and career marks in completions, passing yards, touchdown passes and points responsible for, which combines passing and rushing touchdowns.

Head coach Charlie Weis poured rocket fuel on Quinn’s career when he took over the Irish in 2005. Quinn finished his junior season in 2005 ranked fifth in the country in total offense (334.1 yards per game) and seventh in passing efficiency (158.4).

Quinn continued to light up box scores in his senior season. He was named the Maxwell Award Winner (player of the year) and finished third in Heisman voting after throwing for 3,426 yards and 37 touchdowns. Quinn also set the program record for consecutive pass attempts without an interception with 226 passes between interceptions thrown against Michigan State in game 4 and Army in game 11.

But Quinn’s inability to consistently win big games kept him from receiving the top spot on this list. The Irish nearly beat No. 1 USC in 2005. Quinn also lost at No. 3 USC in 2006 and suffered bowl losses to No. 4 Ohio State (Fiesta Bowl) and No. 11 LSU (Sugar Bowl).

The Cleveland Browns selected Quinn with the No. 22 overall pick in the 2007 NFL Draft’s first round.

3. Angelo Bertelli (1940-43)

It took Bertelli only six games of his senior season to win the 1943 Heisman Trophy. The Marines called him into World War II duty in November after Bertelli already had completed 25 of his 36 passes (69.4%) for 512 yards and 10 touchdowns. Lujack took over the No. 1 Irish offense to complete the national championship season.

But Bertelli established himself as the cog in Notre Dame’s offense before winning Notre Dame’s first Heisman. In 1941, Bertelli played his sophomore season as a single-wing tailback in the box offense, but he still handled most of the passing responsibilities. He led the country in completion percentage (56.9%) on 70-of-123 passing for 1,027 yards and eight touchdowns and finished second in Heisman voting.

Leahy installed his T-formation offense ahead of the 1942 season with Bertelli as its quarterback. His accuracy dipped (72-of-159, 45.3%), but he still threw for 1,039 yards and 10 touchdowns and finished sixth in Heisman voting.

It’s too bad the two-time All-American quarterback couldn’t finish out the 1943 season on the field. The Boston Yanks selected Bertelli with the No. 1 overall pick in the 1944 NFL Draft, but he ended up playing in the All-America Football Conference in 1946 for the Los Angeles Dons following his military service.

4. Joe Theismann (1967-70)

Theismann’s rhyming Heisman campaign fell just short in 1970. He placed as the runner-up behind Stanford quarterback Jim Plunkett after throwing for 2,429 yards and 16 touchdowns on 155-of-268 passing (57.8%). Theismann also finished second in the country in total offense (281.3 yards per game).

Theismann capped his career with a 24-11 win over Texas in the 1971 Cotton Bowl in which he accounted for all three touchdowns (two rushing, one passing). The year prior, the Irish lost 21-17 to the Longhorns. Theismann put Notre Dame up 17-14 with a 24-yard touchdown pass to Jim Yoder with 6:52 left in the 1970 Cotton Bowl, but Texas milked the next 5:39 off the clock for the game-winning touchdown.

When Theismann finished his Notre Dame career, he held the Notre Dame career records for passing yards (4,411) and passing touchdowns (31). He also became just the second Irish player to rush for more than 1,000 yards in a career as a quarterback behind only Paul Hornung.

The Miami Dolphins selected Theismann in the fourth round of the 1971 NFL Draft with pick No. 99.

5. Tom Clements (1971-74)

Clements cemented his spot in Notre Dame lore with a third-down completion from the end zone in Notre Dame’s 1973 Sugar Bowl victory over No. 1 Alabama. With the Irish holding a 24-23 lead, Clements hit backup tight end Robin Weber for a 35-yard completion on third-and-8 to allow Notre Dame to run out the final two minutes of the game and secure a national championship.

Clements was named the Sugar Bowl MVP with 7-of-12 passing for 169 yards and 15 rushes for 74 yards. As a senior in 1974, Clements received a pair of All-American nods and finished fourth in Heisman voting for a season in which he completed 122 of his 215 passes for 1,549 yards and eight touchdowns.

Clements set the Notre Dame record for career wins as a starting quarterback with 29 victories in 34 starts. Both Ron Powlus and Brady Quinn have since tied Clements with 29 wins, but Clements did so in 12 fewer games.

Despite his accolades, Clements was not selected in the 1975 NFL Draft and instead played in the Canadian Football League.

6. Tony Rice (1986-89)

Rice’s career passing numbers look more like Lujack’s and Bertelli’s than Quinn’s and Theismann’s, but that doesn’t prevent him from claiming a spot near the middle of this list. Rice proved he belonged in Notre Dame’s 1988 national championship season.

Rice played arguably his best season in ‘88 as a junior. He finished 70-of-138 passing (50.7%) for 1,176 yards and eight touchdowns and rushed for 700 yards and nine touchdowns. He wrapped up the national championship for the undefeated Irish with an Offensive MVP performance (288 total yards and two passing touchdowns) in the 34-21 win over West Virginia in the 1989 Fiesta Bowl.

In Rice’s senior season, Notre Dame extended its winning streak to 23 games in 1989 until eventual national champ Miami delivered a 27-10 defeat in the regular season finale. The loss to Miami likely ended Rice’s shot at winning the Heisman too. He threw two interceptions and managed only 50 rushing yards on 20 carries in a losing effort. Rice still finished fourth in 1989 Heisman voting and received the Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award as the top senior quarterback in college football.

Rice, who was not selected in the 1990 NFL Draft, continues to hold Notre Dame’s quarterback rushing records for yards in a season (884 in 1989) and a career (1,921). He recorded more rushing touchdowns in a career (23) than any Notre Dame player since 1940. He also sits in second for career passing yards per completion (17.12).

7. Rick Mirer (1989-92)

Mirer follows Rice on this list just as he did in his career. Though Mirer had a much better career as a passer than Rice, his teams couldn’t quite reach national title contention in late November.

When Mirer took over as the starter as a sophomore in 1990, he registered 10th nationally in passing efficiency (138.8) after completing 110 of his 200 passes for 1,824 yards and eight touchdowns with six interceptions. The road wasn’t easy with wins against five teams that finished in the final AP Top 25.

Mirer bumped up his passing efficiency even higher in 1991 (No. 8, 149.3) as a junior with a stat line that included 132-of-234 passing for 2,117 yards and 18 touchdowns with 10 interceptions.

Mirer’s signature moment came in the 1992 Snow Bowl victory over Penn State. He completed a comeback victory in Notre Dame Stadium by throwing a three-yard touchdown pass to Jerome Bettis with 20 seconds remaining. Then Mirer scrambled to find Reggie Brooks in the end zone for a two-point conversion and a 17-16 win.

The Seattle Seahawks selected Mirer with the No. 2 overall pick in the 1993 NFL Draft.

8. Joe Montana (1975-78)

I can already see my email inbox and Twitter mentions lighting up as a result of this decision. When I asked my Twitter followers for their nominations for best Notre Dame quarterback ever, Montana received the most submissions by a large margin. But I couldn’t convince myself to put him higher on the list based on his college résumé alone.

Montana offered a glimpse of what his NFL career would become when he led Notre Dame’s 1979 Cotton Bowl comeback against Houston. He seemed to have a knack for comebacks throughout his college and pro career. The Irish trailed 34-12 midway through the fourth quarter, but still managed to win.

Montana, who earlier threw four interceptions, set up the game-winning extra point with a dart to wide receiver Kris Haines for an 8-yard touchdown pass as time expired. Montana won bowl MVP honors in the 35-34 victory.

The Cotton Bowl was a fitting location to end Montana’s Notre Dame career. The year prior, Montana and the Irish earned a national championship by defeating No. 1 Texas. Montana started the season as the third-string quarterback before finding his way into the lineup.

Montana, who finished his Notre Dame career 268-of-515 passing (52%) for 4,121 yards with 25 passing touchdowns, 14 rushing touchdowns and 25 interceptions, was selected by the San Francisco 49ers in the third round of the 1979 NFL Draft with the No. 82 pick.

9. Jimmy Clausen (2007-09)

Clausen’s 2009 season might be the best statistical season for a quarterback in Notre Dame history. He set the program record for 300-yard passing games in a season with seven, tied Bob Williams for the best passing efficiency mark (161.4) in a season, and he threw 160 passes in between interceptions against Washington and Navy, the second-longest streak in school history behind Quinn's 226.

Clausen’s 2009 numbers also stacked up well against his peers with his passing efficiency ranking third in the FBS and his total offensive yards per game (302.3) ranking eighth.

But wins were hard to come by for Clausen. He’s the only quarterback on this list with a losing record (16-18) as a starter. His monster 2009 season was wasted by a dreadful defense and ended with Weis being fired.

Clausen, who also holds program records for completions per game in a career (19.9) and lowest career interception percentage (2.432%), was selected by the Carolina Panthers in the second round of the 2010 NFL Draft with pick No. 48.

10. Bob Williams (1947-50)

Leahy sure knew how to use quarterbacks, huh? Williams, who was on the freshman squad when Notre Dame won its national championship in 1946, led the Irish to a title in 1949. He did so by setting program records in passing yards (1,374) and passing efficiency (161.4).

Williams’ passing yards record stood until John Huarte blew by it in 1964 with 2,062 yards. Williams’ passing efficiency mark has been matched only by Clausen in 2009.

Teammate Leon Hart won the 1949 Heisman as Williams finished sixth in the country in total offense with 1,437 yards. The 1950 Irish didn’t successfully defend their title, but Williams was 10th in the country with 99 completions as he registered his second All-American honor.

The Chicago Bears selected Williams with the No. 2 overall pick in the 1951 NFL Draft.

search_result.title: Ohio State football has won 7 national championships
search_result.text:
Updated Jan. 21, 2025, 4:28 p.m. ET

College football crowned a champion for well over a century (1869-1998) without a title game and went even longer (until 2014) before instituting a playoff. For that reason, declaring how many titles a team owns is not as straightforward as one might think.

In Ohio State's case, following Monday's College Football Playoff win over Notre Dame, the Buckeyes claim nine national championships — 1942, 1954, 1957, 1961, 1968, 1970, 2002, 2014 and 2024. The Dispatch counts seven of these, omitting 1961, when the Buckeyes were awarded the national championship by the Football Writers Association of America, and 1970, when they were honored by the National Football Foundation.

The 1961 Buckeyes finished 8-0-1 and ended up No. 2 in the final Associated Press and United Press International polls behind undefeated Alabama (11-0). The NFF also declared the Crimson Tide to be the top team in the country.

In 1970, OSU went 9-1, and while the NFF named the Buckeyes co-national champions alongside Texas (11-1), UPI gave the nod to Texas. The AP honored Nebraska (11-0-1), which received 39 of 52 first-place votes. Notre Dame (10-1) received eight first-place votes, Texas three and Ohio State none. The FWAA awarded the MacArthur Bowl Trophy to the Longhorns.

For the seven years that The Dispatch recognizes, Ohio State either won the designated national championship game (2002, 2014, 2024) or it was voted No. 1 in either the AP or UPI polls.

This has long been the Dispatch's policy.

Here, for instance, is what the paper said after the 2014 team won the title:

Say it slowly and let it sink in. It really happened. You aren't dreaming. The Ohio State Buckeyes, counted out so many times this season, are the kings of college football. This resilient 2014 team, a combination of 1968 youth and 2002 grit, overcame four turnovers to roll over Oregon 42-20 in the championship game of the inaugural College Football Playoff at AT&T Stadium last night. Counted out after losing Braxton Miller before the season and falling to Virginia Tech in their second game, the Buckeyes (14-1) won their sixth national championship in school history in front of a mostly Ohio State crowd of 85,689.

And consider what the paper wrote on Jan. 4, 2003:

TEMPE, Ariz. — Cie Grant delivered the final uppercut for Ohio State last night in what will go down in history as one of college football's great upset knockouts. The senior linebacker forced a bad pass by Miami quarterback Ken Dorsey on fourth down from the 1-yard line in the second overtime. That made Maurice Clarett's 5-yard touchdown run moments earlier the game-winner in a 31-24 victory over the heavily favored Hurricanes. And it made the Buckeyes the national champions. "It was two great heavyweights slugging it out and our guys came up with the win," coach Jim Tressel said. The rest of the Buckeyes and many of their fans charged the field and locked in a jubilant throng that enjoyed fireworks, confetti and hugs throughout. The rest of the predominantly OSU crowd of 77,502 in Sun Devil Stadium rocked in the glow of the school's first national championship since 1968 and fifth overall

But whether you argue Ohio State has won seven championships or believe the number is nine, there is no debate that Monday's 34-23 win over Notre Dame was a victory fans will remember.

Jan. 19, 2026 Updated Jan. 20, 2026, 12:56 a.m. ET

Indiana football is the national champion.

The No. 1-ranked Hoosiers defeated No. 10 Miami 27-21 in the 2026 College Football Playoff national championship game on Monday, Jan. 19, from Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida.

With the win, the Hoosiers (16-0) finished off the worst-to-first story with the program's first championship in program history. Indiana is the first team to win its first national title since Florida did so in 1996.

Jamari Sharpe intercepted a pass from Miami quarterback Carson Beck with 44 seconds left to clinch the victory for the Hoosiers. The Hurricanes were looking for a touchdown drive to potentially snatch a victory in a game they never led.

Fernando Mendoza finished 16-of-27 passing for 186 yards, adding a rushing touchdown in the fourth quarter that ended up being the difference for Indiana. Omar Cooper Jr. had five catches for 71 yards, while Charlie Becker added four catches for 65 yards ― including a pair of 19-yard catches late on third and fourth downs, respectively.

Mark Fletcher had 112 rushing yards and two touchdowns, including a 57-yard scamper in the third quarter after Miami was shut out in the first half. Beck finished with 232 passing yards, one touchdown and an interception. Malachi Toney had 10 catches for 122 yards and a score for Miami.

Despite being the lower seed in the CFB bracket, Miami had the "homefield advantage" for the championship game, which was hosted at the Hurricanes' home venue at Hard Rock Stadium.

Indiana wins national championship

Indiana completes a perfect 16-0 season with a 27-21 win over Miami in the 2026 national championship game. It's the first national title in program history for the Hoosiers.

"It took a lot to get here. But I'll tell you what it took to come out ahead in this game: It took a lot of guts," Indiana coach Curt Cignetti said postgame.

"We won the national championship at Indiana University. It can be done."

Jamari Sharpe intercepts Carson Beck to clinch Indiana championship

Jamari Sharpe intercepts a pass from Carson Beck to end Miami's drive and clinch the first national title in Indiana football history.

Fernando Mendoza will kneel the ball with 44 seconds left in the game.

Nico Radicic extends Indiana lead with field goal

Indiana adds three points on a Nico Radicic 35-yard field goal to extend the Indiana lead to 27-21 with 1:42 left in the game.

The scoring drive is 11 plays for 58 yards and takes 4:55 off the game clock.

Miami needs a touchdown to win and has no timeouts remaining.

Who is Fernando Mendoza's mom?

Fernando Mendoza's mother — Elsa Mendoza — is shown every time the Indiana QB makes a big play. She was the first one he thanked when he accepted his Heisman Trophy in December.

Here’s what you need to know about Mendoza’s mom, a former tennis star at Miami.

Malachi Toney scores rushing touchdown

Miami is not done yet. Malachi Toney weaves his way for a 22-yard touchdown pitch from Carson Beck to cut the Indiana lead to 24-21 with 6:37 left in the contest. Miami's scoring drive is eight plays for 91 yards and takes 2:34 off the clock.

Indiana will need to respond again.

Fernando Mendoza rushing touchdown extends Indiana lead

Curt Cignetti opts to trust his offense on a pair of fourth-down attempts, and it pays off. Fernando Mendoza scores on a 12-yard run on fourth-and-5 from the Miami 12-yard line to extend Indiana's lead to 24-14 with 9:11 left in the game.

Mendoza also completed a 19-yard back-shoulder throw to Charlie Becker on fourth-and-5 from the Miami 37-yard line to keep Indiana's drive alive.

The scoring drive is 12 plays for 75 yards and takes 5:39 off the game clock. Gutsy drive and calls from Cignetti.

Mark Fletcher scores again for Miami

Miami responds to the blocked kick with a touchdown drive to cut the lead to 17-14 with 14:57 left in the game. Mark Fletcher Jr. scores his second touchdown of the game, this one from 3 yards out.

Fletcher has 16 rushes for 109 yards and two scores. The scoring drive is 10 plays of 81 yards and takes 5:03 off the game clock.

End of third quarter: Indiana 17, Miami 7

Indiana leads Miami 17-7 entering the fourth quarter. However, Miami is driving in the Indiana red zone at the 3-yard line with the chance to cut the game to one score again.

Indiana blocks punt, scores touchdown

With Miami pinned back on fourth down, Mikail Kamara blocks the punt and Isaiah Jones recovers the ball in the end zone for a touchdown. Indiana leads 17-7 with 5:04 left in the third quarter.

Crucial play from the Hoosiers' special teams with the offense struggling. According to Indiana football's X account (formerly Twitter), that's the first blocked punt returned for a touchdown in CFP history.

Mark Fletcher scores long TD to get Miami back in game

Mark Fletcher Jr. breaks out for a 57-yard touchdown run to cut Indiana's lead to 10-7 with 11:06 left in the third quarter. Fletcher had just 26 yards in the first half.

The scoring drive is two plays for 62 yards and takes 46 seconds off the clock.

Rueben Bain sacks Fernando Mendoza to force Indiana punt

Indiana punts on its first possession of the second half, following a third-down sack from Rueben Bain Jr. Miami does not pay for its bailout for the Hoosiers on a third-and-long facemask call.

Miami will begin its first drive of the second half from its own 38-yard line.

Curt Cignetti calls out officiating in first half against Fernando Mendoza

Indiana coach Curt Cignetti's team holds a 10-0 halftime lead over Miami. Despite the Hoosiers being 30 game minutes from the first national championship in school history, Cignetti was upset with the officiating in the first half in an interview with ESPN:

"Well, there's three personal fouls on the quarterback not called in one drive that need to be called because they're obvious personal fouls," Cignetti said at halftime. "I'm all for letting them play, but when you cross the line, you gotta call it. And they were black and white calls."

Carter Davis' 50-yard field goal doinks off the right upright and Miami's first scoring opportunity is denied. Indiana leads 10-0 with 33 seconds left in the first half.

Carson Beck NIL deal with Miami

Carson Beck transferred to Miami from Georgia last offseason for a reported big NIL deal. According to a report from Pete Nakos of On3 in June, Beck's NIL deal is between $3 million and $3.2 million from the Hurricanes.

The initial reports for Beck's NIL deal with Miami came in at $4 million.

Indiana holds a 3-0 lead after one quarter of play in the national championship game. The Hoosiers got on the board with a 34-yard field goal. Meanwhile, Miami has three punts and has gone three-and-out on consecutive drives.

The Hoosiers outgained Miami 83-18 in the first.

Jakobe Thomas appears to make helmet-to-helmet contact on Fernando Mendoza on a hard hit after Mendoza hands the ball off. However, no flag was thrown and it results in a field goal for the Hoosiers on a long drive.

Indiana draws first blood with field goal

Indiana draws first blood with a 34-yard field goal from Nicolas Radicic to give the Hoosiers a 3-0 lead with 2:42 remaining in the first half.

The scoring drive is 12 plays for 55 yards and takes 5:56 off the game clock. Fernando Mendoza takes a couple of hard hits and appears to be bleeding from his lower lip following a helmet hit from a Miami defender.

Miami is able to pick up a first down on its opening drive, but punts from its own 48-yard line after the drive stalls out.

Indiana begins its first drive from its own 5-yard line, but punts after gaining one first down as well.

The Hurricanes begin their second drive from their own 23-yard line following a holding penalty on the punt return.

Jan. 20, 2025 Updated Jan. 21, 2025, 12:39 p.m. ET

The Ohio State Buckeyes are national champions.

A season that appeared lost after a shocking 13-10 loss to Michigan on Nov. 30 ended in jubilation on Monday when the Buckeyes defeated Notre Dame 34-23 in the College Football Playoff championship at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.

Quinshon Judkins scored three touchdowns to lead Ohio State, which finished the season 14-2 and won its first national title since 2014.

The Buckeyes scored 21 unanswered points in the first half to take a 21-7 halftime lead, then opened the second half with another touchdown drive to stretch the lead to 28-7. Notre Dame hung around and cut the lead to 31-23 with 4:15 to play in the game, but the Buckeyes put together a long drive and Jayden Fielding kicked 33-yard field goal with 26 seconds remaining to seal it.

The win capped a stirring run in the CFP's new expanded 12-team format that saw the eighth-seeded Buckeyes win playoff games against Tennessee, Oregon and Texas before taking on the Fighting Irish for the title.

This is the Buckeyes' seventh national title. It also gave the Big Ten back-to-back national champions for the first time since 1942. Last year's champion, Michigan, was the first Big Ten team to win a national title in football since Ohio State won it in 2014.

The Fighting Irish have won eight national titles but have not won one since 1988.

The win raised coach Ryan Day's record to 70-10 in six years at Ohio State. Day is first nationally among all FBScoaches with an .875 winning percentage.

Notre Dame reached the title game with playoff wins against Indiana, Georgia and Penn State.

By reaching the final, Ohio State earned $20 million for the Big Ten. As an independent, Notre Dame gets to keep all $20 million it received for its CFP run.

When did Ohio State win its national championships?

This is the Buckeyes' seventh national football title.

July 2, 2021, 7:02 a.m. ET

Winning national championships is always at the top of the to-do list for Alabama athletics, but a close second is defeating SEC counterparts on the way to a conference championship. The road to an SEC title is always sweeter when those wins include victories over Auburn and Tennessee.

Alabama had a good 2020-21 season versus its in-state rival, going 12-5 against the Tigers. The Crimson Tide handily defeated Auburn 42-13 in the Iron Bowl, and the men's and women's basketball teams went a combined 4-0 vs the Tigers, winning two games apiece. The softball team swept the season series 3-0. Gymnastics came out on top of its lone head-to-head meeting. Baseball broke the hearts of Auburn fans, by winning two of three games via walk-offs.

GIVING BACK: Bo Scarborough excited to run July football clinic with former Alabama players

Tennessee proved to be a more difficult adversary, as each school won 10 head-to-head contests. The Crimson Tide easily defeated the Volunteers 48-17 in football. Softball won three of four, while men’s basketball swept the series 2-0. The baseball team did struggle, winning two of five games.

Alabama athletics had some big winners in the 2020-21 school year.

Despite COVID-19, it was business as usual for Crimson Tide football, which went 13-0 and won the national championship.

The softball team had a memorable season despite losing in the semifinals of the Women’s College World Series. The team finished 52-9 and recorded its 13th 50-win season in the Patrick Murphy era en route to winning the SEC Tournament.

Men's basketball, led by SEC Coach of the Year Nate Oats, won the SEC regular-season and tournament titles on the way to a Sweet 16 berth in the NCAA Tournament.

Gymnastics won the SEC championship for the first time since 2015, and junior gymnast Shallon Olsen will be heading to Tokyo for the Olympics.

Here’s how Alabama’s sports teams stacked up in the 2020-21 season. The rankings were derived by a vote of the sports staff of The Tuscaloosa News:

1. Football

Coach: Nick Saban

Record: 13-0 (10-0 regular season)

The Crimson Tide “rebounded” from a 10-2 season in 2019 to claim its sixth national championship under Nick Saban. This team also produced six first-round picks in the 2021 NFL Draft, which is tied for the most by a school in history (2004 Miami Hurricanes).

2. Softball

3. Men’s basketball

Coach: Nate Oats

Record: 26-7 (16-2 SEC regular season)

NCAA finish: Lost to UCLA in Sweet 16

Alabama captured its first SEC regular-season title since 2002 and first conference tournament championship since 1991.

4. Gymnastics

NCAA finish: Placed fifth out of eight teams in NCAA Championships

The Crimson Tide won its third SEC championship (2014 and '15) under Dana Duckworth.

5. Women’s swimming and diving

Coach: Ozzie Quevedo

Record: 2-3 in regular season (1-2 SEC)

SEC finish: Fourth at SEC Championship

NCAA finish: Fifth in NCAA Championships

Alabama won the 400 freestyle at the NCAA Championships in a school-record time, marking UA's first national relay title. The fifth-place finish is the highest in school history.

Coach: Dan Waters

SEC finish: Second at SEC Championship

NCAA finish: Eighth at NCAA Championships

The Crimson Tide finished with 280 points and an eighth-place finish at the NCAA Championships, which marks the second-highest finish ever (behind fifth place in 1988).

Dec. 30, 2025 Updated Jan. 2, 2026, 7:48 p.m. ET

The year 2025 had some of everything. State championships. National championships. Major Leaguers, Coaches retiring and more.

Check out the top Holland-area sports stories of 2025:

Holland area has two major leaguers

Grant Wolfram was called up to the Major Leagues for the second time - and second team - this season on Saturday.

And it came in storybook fashion.

This time, he finally got to make his long-awaited Major League debut - in his home state.

The Holland native and Hamilton graduate pitched for the Baltimore Orioles in a 6-2 loss to the Detroit Tigers at Comerica Park in Detroit.

Wolfram came into the game in the bottom of the seventh inning with two outs and a runner on second. His family and Hamilton coach Brian Grabinski were in the stands along with others from the Hamilton and Holland area who made the trip across the state.

Meanwhile, Saugatuck native Blake Dunn started the season on the roster of the Cincinnati Reds, making it the first time multiple area players have been in the majors the same season.

GVSU women's basketball claims NCAA title

All season the Grand Valley State women's basketball team thought it would finally be their year.

The Lakers were in the Final Four a couple of years ago, still on their rise, then lost their starting point guard to injury last year.

This year, everyone was healthy and the team embraced the team having 11 starters and used that depth and talent to claim the NCAA Division II national championship.

The Lakers defeated Cal State-Dominguez Hills 70-58 March 28 in Pittsburgh to finish the season 38-2 an earn the program's first NCAA title since 2006 in women's basketball and 30th overall, making Allendale a pretty good title town.

"It is such an awesome feeling. This is the ultimate end goal for any team. I am so proud to be a part of this team," GVSU senior Rylie Bisballe said.

Calvary wins first ever state title; HC cross wins too

A few years ago, Holland Calvary started its latest wave of runners.

It was a pack of eighth graders who ended up running at the state tournament.

Three years later, the junior-led Crusaders made history by winning the first state championship in school history.

"This state title means a lot to our small community. It’s our first state championship in our schools history. We really focus on process-related goals rather than outcome-related ones, so seeing that our process-driven approach can lead to a state title is incredibly encouraging. Everything we do in sports is an extension of what we do in our school every day, all day long, which makes it easy for the kids to understand the direction we want to take with our program," Calvary coach Richard Laninga said. "Things really started to take off when this junior class fully bought into that idea, when they were younger. They began running more, which allowed us to do more in our training. That buy-in has inspired others in the program, even our current younger runners, to improve and push themselves."

Calvary won the Division 4 boys state championship on Saturday, Nov. 1, at Michigan International Speedway, scoring 110 points to hold off Maple City Glen Lake by 21 points for the title.

The Crusaders were not the only team to claim a state title from the Holland area, which had 10 teams qualify.

The Holland Christian girls won the Division 2 state title.

The Maroons scored 116 to hold off Otsego by just six points.

"It means so much to our team," sophomore Avery Engbers said. "We have been working hard not only this season but throughout the whole summer together and to finally do what we have been working do hard for felt so good."

4 iconic coaches retire

For two decades, the Zeeland West program has been a constant playoff presence and state title contender.

John Shillito has been the only head coach that the Dux have ever known in program history and has led Zeeland West to five state titles behind the vaunted Wing-T offense.

Yes the Dux have won a state title in 20% of their football seasons and made the playoffs 18 of their 20 years, winning at least 10 games eight times.

Meanwhile, Holland Christian boys swim coach Todd Smeenge has also retired.

He led the Maroons to multiple state championships and has been a mainstay on the deck for the past three decades.

Later in the year, Zeeland East track and field coach Ralph Neal announced his retirement. He led the Chix to multiple MHSAA and MITCA team state championships and the throws expert produced a record number of all-state athletes in the shot put and discus.

West Ottawa soccer coach Brent Wyckoff also stepped down after nearly a quarter century leading the Panthers. He guided several players to the NCAA Division I level.

Isabel Anaya goes undefeated, wins first girls wrestling title

In the past four years, girls wrestling has gone from is infancy to the fastest growing sport in the state.

West Ottawa's Isabel Anaya has been the leading trailblazer in the area.

She was the first girls all-state wrestler in the area, the first two-, three- and four-time all-state wrestler in area history. She was the first female wrestler to reach 100 wins and the first to reach a state final.

Anaya saved the best for last. She is the first girls wrestler in area history to be a state champion - and finish a season undefeated.

"It happened so fast and I saw my coaches celebrating and that is when I knew. It honestly means so much to me. I would come to state earlier in my career and feel like that was never going to be me. But this year, I was so excited and I knew this was going to be my year," Anaya said. "It hasn't really settled, but I am proud to have set a standard that other girls will be able to reach."

Track state titles abound, swimming too

As Emma Gunnett made her move, the West Ottawa girls 4x800 relay team could start to feel it.

Gunnett passed Oak Park on the third leg and handed to Collette Wierks who kept the pace on the first lap, then left the field behind on the second lap as the Panthers repeated as Division 1 state champions in the 4x800 on Saturday, May 31, at East Kentwood.

"The girls took care of business. It takes all four and we have the depth," West Ottawa coach Kyle Barnes said. "This is a really big deal for the program. We thought we could win last year and pulled kind of an upset, and thought we could this year. Hopefully, we can win again next year."

Collette Wierks also won the 800 meters state title, while Helen Sachs won the 3,200 meters and was second in the 1,600 meters.

In swimming, Zeeland's Owen Stevens and Holland Christian's Camryn Siegers each won a pair of individual state championships in the pool and Hamilton's Josi Popma and Holland Christian's Parker Schut each won diving state titles.

GVSU claims NCAA title in women's track and cross

The Grand Valley State women's track and field team proved that every point counts this weekend as the Lakers claimed the NCAA Division II national championship by a single point.

GVSU scored 60 points to hold off Adams State (59) and the rest of the field.

"This team goes beyond just putting points on a scoreboard," Erika Beistle said. "All of the laughs, struggles and memories made a long way certainly top everything. We all did our part to etch our names into GVSU history. This had been something we've all wanted to accomplish since day one, and to finally achieve that goal is something so very special."

After Erika Beistle won the discus and Maggie Stevenson was second, Shelby Ulven took second in the hammer throw and Alaina Diaz was second in the long jump earlier in the week, the Lakers earned some more trophies on the final day.

The Lakers also won the NCAA title in women's cross country in the fall.

Hope football hosts NCAA playoff game for second time

The Hope College football team knew it had done enough to make the playoffs.

It turns out, it was enough to earn a bye - and host a second-round game.

The Flying Dutchmen will host the University of Wisconsin–La Crosse in an NCAA Division III second-round playoff game at noon Saturday, Nov. 29, at Ray & Sue Smith Stadium.

Hope (9-1) and Wisconsin–La Crosse (7-2) of the Wisconsin Intercollegiate Athletic Conference both received at-large bids and first-round byes in the 40-team field.

Whitecaps win Midwest League title

The West Michigan Whitecaps are the Midwest League champions for the first time in a decade.

The Whitecaps defeated the Cedar Rapids Kernels 3-1 in Game 2 on Tuesday, Sept. 16, to claim their first Midwest League title since 2016, sweeping the best-of-three series.

This year has been like no other in the entire Tigers organization.

"I have never seen anything close to this - nothing close," Whitecaps manager Tony Cappuccilli said. "That is the best part for us. We have relationships with players starting in spring training. Being able to follow that success with them and other coaches and see that success is so much fun. We have had guys have career-type years. It has made it a fun vibe in the clubhouse."

Gulker leads Ferris State to national title

Zeeland West graduate Carson Gulker has been a part of an NCAA Division II dynasty.

The H-back was pivotal in Ferris State's 42-21 win over Harding in the Division II championship game on Dec. 20. It is the fourth national title in five years for the Bulldogs.

Gulker, a former all-state quarterback, had three catches for 52 yards and a touchdown. He also rushed seven times for 41 yards and was 2-for-2 passing for 47 yards.

Holland-area players lead Calvin volleyball to NCAA quarters

The stunning postseason run for the Calvin University volleyball team ended in the NCAA quarterfinals.

The No. 19 Knights were defeated by No. 3 Wisconsin-Oshkosh, 25-13, 26-24, 25-21 in the NCAA Division III national quarterfinals on Wednesday, Dec. 3, at Illinois Wesleyan.

Calvin finished the season 28-3, upsetting No. 7 Hope for the MIAA Tournament title, then knocking off No. 13 Wisconsin-Whitewater and No. 2 Illinois Wesleyan in the NCAA tournament.

"Oshkosh has a ton of talent and came out strong," Calvin coach Amber Warners said. "We might have come out with too many nerves. But we didn't give up and that is a tribute to what they have done all year. I am so proud of this group. I don't think anyone had Elite Eight on their goal list, though we knew we were capable of it. This is our team that has improved the most from beginning to end."

Updated Jan. 2, 2025, 10:13 p.m. ET

Penn State football must conquer once-upon rival Notre Dame to play for its first national championship in nearly four decades.

The Nittany Lions, now 13-2 after their College Football Playoff victory over Boise State, will face the Fighting Irish in the CFP semifinals in next week's Orange Bowl.

The Irish, who have now won 12 straight games, advanced to college football's version of the Final Four by strangling the Georgia Bulldogs, 23-10, in Thursday's Sugar Bowl. The game was delayed by a day in the aftermath of the truck attack that killed 14 people and wounded dozens of others in New Orleans' French Quarter.

The Lions, meanwhile, made these semifinals by grinding down Boise on New Year's Eve, 31-14. In the process, PSU stayed undefeated in the Fiesta Bowl (8-0) and produced two 1,000-yard rushers in the same season (Nick Singleton, Kaytron Allen) for the first time in school history.

Penn State and Notre Dame will battle on Jan. 9 in Miami Gardens' Hard Rock Stadium (7:30 p.m., ESPN) for a spot in the first national championship game of this expanded playoff format. The winner faces the survivor of the Texas-Ohio State semifinal. The title game will be held on Jan. 20 in Atlanta.

The Lions and Fighting Irish were once yearly rivals, when both played independent schedules. They met each season from 1981 through 1992 and again in 2006-07. The series is even at 9-9 with one tie.

Penn State in the Orange Bowl

Penn State football has played in five Orange Bowls in program history, posting a 4-1 record. The only loss came against Oklahoma (25-10) in the 1985 national championship game.

In the Lions' last Orange Bowl, they defeated Florida State, 26-23, in three overtimes to end their 2005 season at 11-1 and ranked No. 3 nationally.

Penn State CFP Orange Bowl prediction

The Notre Dame defense may be the best quarterback Drew Allar and the Lions have faced all season. Plus, the Fighting Irish are the nation's hottest team, outside of undefeated Oregon, with 11 straight victories.

Here's why they Lions may not be able to overcome streaking Notre Dame.

Penn State tickets for the Orange Bowl

Penn State ticket requests for the Orange Bowl will be available through the university this week. Ticket requests must be submitted by 5 p.m. Thursday.

Penn State football vs. Notre Dame odds

The Lions are listed with a +105 moneyline against Notre Dame. The Fighting Irish are -125, according to BetMGM.

Penn State is an early 1.5-point underdog in the game with an over/under of 46.5 points.

When are CFP semifinals?

The first CFP semifinal game will be between Penn State and Notre Dame on Jan. 9 in the Orange Bowl. It will begin at 7:30 p.m. and will be televised by ESPN.

The second CFP semifinal game will between Texas and Ohio State on Jan. 10 in the Cotton Bowl. It also will begin at 7:30 p.m., televised by ESPN.

What bowl games are in CFP?

The six biggest, traditional bowls are the sites of the CFP quarterfinals and semifinals.

The quarterfinals featured the Fiesta Bowl on New Year's Eve (Penn State vs. Boise State) and the Peach Bowl, Rose Bowl and Sugar Bowl on New Year's Day.

The semifinals feature the Orange Bowl on Jan. 9 and the Cotton Bowl on Jan. 10.

CFP schedule

The semifinals will be played on Jan. 9 at the Orange Bowl (Penn State vs. Notre Dame, 7:30 p.m.) and on Jan. 10 at the Cotton Bowl (Texas vs. Ohio State, 7:30 p.m.).

The national championship game will be played at Atlanta's Mercedes-Benz Stadium on Jan. 20, 7:30 p.m.
